questions.question: Lady Pawsington rolls a fair 6-sided die. What's the probability of rolling a 3?
questions.explanation: P(3) = 1/6 â‰ˆ 0.167. Lady Pawsington's dice probability!

questions.question: Professor Tinkles has a bag with 3 red balls and 2 blue balls. What's the probability of drawing a red ball?
questions.explanation: P(red) = 3/(3+2) = 3/5 = 0.6. Professor Tinkles' ball probability!

questions.question: Sir Whiskersworth flips a fair coin twice. What's the probability of getting heads both times?
questions.explanation: P(HH) = (1/2) Ã— (1/2) = 1/4 = 0.25. Sir Whiskersworth's coin probability!

questions.question: Inspector Clawson has 5 suspects. What's the probability of randomly selecting the guilty one?
questions.explanation: P(guilty) = 1/5 = 0.2. The Inspector's suspect probability!

questions.question: Lady Pawsington draws 2 cards from a deck of 52. What's the probability both are hearts?
questions.explanation: P(2 hearts) = (13/52) Ã— (12/51) = 156/2652 â‰ˆ 0.059. Lady Pawsington's card probability!

questions.question: Professor Tinkles has 4 cats and 3 dogs. What's the probability of randomly selecting a cat?
questions.explanation: P(cat) = 4/(4+3) = 4/7 â‰ˆ 0.571. Professor Tinkles' pet probability!

questions.question: Sir Whiskersworth rolls two dice. What's the probability of getting a sum of 7?
questions.explanation: P(sum=7) = 6/36 = 1/6 â‰ˆ 0.167. Sir Whiskersworth's dice sum!

questions.question: Inspector Clawson has 3 keys and 1 lock. What's the probability of opening it on the first try?
questions.explanation: P(success) = 1/3 â‰ˆ 0.333. The Inspector's key probability!

questions.question: Lady Pawsington has 6 books: 2 math, 2 science, 2 history. What's the probability of randomly selecting a math book?
questions.explanation: P(math) = 2/6 = 1/3 â‰ˆ 0.333. Lady Pawsington's book probability!

questions.question: Professor Tinkles flips a coin 3 times. What's the probability of getting exactly 2 heads?
questions.explanation: P(2 heads) = C(3,2) Ã— (1/2)Â³ = 3 Ã— 1/8 = 3/8 = 0.375. Professor Tinkles' combination probability!

questions.question: Sir Whiskersworth has 5 different colored balls. How many ways can he arrange 3 of them?
questions.explanation: P(5,3) = 5!/(5-3)! = 5!/2! = 120/2 = 60. Sir Whiskersworth's permutation!

questions.question: Inspector Clawson needs to choose 2 assistants from 4 candidates. How many combinations?
questions.explanation: C(4,2) = 4!/(2! Ã— 2!) = 24/4 = 6. The Inspector's combination choice!

questions.question: Lady Pawsington has 8 different books. How many ways can she arrange them on a shelf?
questions.explanation: 8! = 8 Ã— 7 Ã— 6 Ã— 5 Ã— 4 Ã— 3 Ã— 2 Ã— 1 = 40320. Lady Pawsington's book arrangement!

questions.question: Professor Tinkles draws 3 cards from a deck. What's the probability all are spades?
questions.explanation: P(3 spades) = (13/52) Ã— (12/51) Ã— (11/50) â‰ˆ 0.0129. Professor Tinkles' spade probability!

questions.question: Sir Whiskersworth has 6 different colored scarves. How many ways can he choose 2 to wear?
questions.explanation: C(6,2) = 6!/(2! Ã— 4!) = 720/(2 Ã— 24) = 15. Sir Whiskersworth's scarf combination!

questions.question: Inspector Clawson has a 70% chance of solving a case. What's the probability he won't solve it?
questions.explanation: P(not solving) = 1 - 0.7 = 0.3. The Inspector's complement probability!

questions.question: Lady Pawsington rolls a die. What's the probability of getting an even number?
questions.explanation: P(even) = 3/6 = 1/2 = 0.5. Lady Pawsington's even number probability!

questions.question: Professor Tinkles has 4 red marbles and 6 blue marbles. What's the probability of drawing a red marble?
questions.explanation: P(red) = 4/(4+6) = 4/10 = 0.4. Professor Tinkles' marble probability!

questions.question: Sir Whiskersworth flips a coin and rolls a die. What's the probability of heads AND a 6?
questions.explanation: P(H and 6) = (1/2) Ã— (1/6) = 1/12 â‰ˆ 0.083. Sir Whiskersworth's independent events!

questions.question: Inspector Clawson has 3 suspects: A, B, C. What's the probability A is guilty?
questions.explanation: P(A guilty) = 1/3 â‰ˆ 0.333. The Inspector's suspect probability!

questions.question: Lady Pawsington has 5 different colored pens. How many ways can she choose 2?
questions.explanation: C(5,2) = 5!/(2! Ã— 3!) = 120/(2 Ã— 6) = 10. Lady Pawsington's pen combination!

questions.question: Professor Tinkles draws 2 cards from a deck. What's the probability both are aces?
questions.explanation: P(2 aces) = (4/52) Ã— (3/51) = 12/2652 â‰ˆ 0.0045. Professor Tinkles' ace probability!

questions.question: Sir Whiskersworth has 7 different books. How many ways can he arrange 4 of them?
questions.explanation: P(7,4) = 7!/(7-4)! = 7!/3! = 5040/6 = 840. Sir Whiskersworth's book permutation!

questions.question: Inspector Clawson has a 60% chance of finding a clue. What's the probability he finds at least one clue in 2 attempts?
questions.explanation: P(at least 1) = 1 - P(none) = 1 - (0.4)Â² = 1 - 0.16 = 0.84. The Inspector's success probability!

questions.question: Lady Pawsington has 6 different colored scarves. How many ways can she arrange them in a row?
questions.explanation: 6! = 6 Ã— 5 Ã— 4 Ã— 3 Ã— 2 Ã— 1 = 720. Lady Pawsington's scarf arrangement!
